We're going to be talking about the crime world around us your everyday encounters with physics and particular with quantum physics.

And what I'm going to be doing is showing you a top 10 list of the top 10 things that use quantum mechanics that you encounter in your everyday life starting with number 10 DVDs DVDs employee a particular physics phenomenon called a fraction and the way that you can see that as if you shine light on a DVD it actually works better with a CD than a DVD but those are a little bit harder to find you will see that the white light is going to separate into its constituent colors, which are the colors of the rainbow and this occurs due to a process called to fraction.

The quantum theory can describe not only diffraction but all other Optics related interference phenomena as well.
And on the right here.
We have a picture of a CD that is showing some of those rainbow light patterns number 9 is partial reflection of light.
You probably have seen this where you look at a mirror at a window.

during the day you pretty much can see through the window but at night it acts like a mirror and reflects back at you but turns out it does that during the day too if you look closely you can also see your reflection is shown in the picture here so light has this to fold procedure where it does what's called Parson reflection it sometimes or flex and it sometimes transmits through the window and

This actually results from an interference phenomenon between Reflections off the top and the bottom surface of the glass and it can be explained entirely with our quantum theory of light and we go through the details of this in the third module of the course.

Number 8 transparent Windows the windows that you look through are made out of window glass which is an amorphous solid that is transparent to light because of the way that the Silicon in the oxygen atoms that make up the window glass arrange themselves in the solid state glass is an insulator which means that electrical current will not flow through it.

It turns out the glass so we'll absorb ultraviolet light even though it lets visible light through and this is why you don't get a sunburn when you driving your car on a sunny day unless of course you open your window and stick your arm out.

And the reason why it behaves this way is described completely by quantum mechanics, but we're not going to have an opportunity to go through those details in this class number 7 on our list is Metals similar to Glass metals.
Which conduct electricity do so because of the way in which they are a solid they have with called a sea of electrons in them.
This electron sea is Created from the Pauli Exclusion Principle, which some of you may have heard from and since the electrons are so-called fermions.

The fermions are quantum particles that don't like each other so they stay apart and you can only understand this via quantum theory this sea of electrons is not created in classical physics world, but we're not going to cover this material in this particular course number 6 on our list is smoke detectors meant out of realize but every smoke detector has got some radioactive material in it the smoke detectors use this radioactive element, which is called americium this material emits alpha particles and the alpha particles create a current
That goes between two.
Electrical plates that are held at different voltages and because the americium releases these alpha particles at a fairly constant rate, even though each releases random.
The current flow is a fairly constant current when there's no smoke around but when the smoke enters the Chamber of the current changes and that allows you to detect the smoke

this radioactive decay of americium as in the radioactive decay of any element is a purely Quantum phenomenon, but it's not one that we're going to discuss in detail in this class know it however that because smoke detectors do contain this radioactive material.

You should never dispose of them in the garbage, but you need to take them to the appropriate hazardous waste disposal location for they can properly handle the radiation component of the smoke detector.
